newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Situation on Mir under control after accident.
newsitem.headline: Situation on Mir under control after accident.

text.p: Mission control and the three-man crew are fully in control of the situation on the space station Mir three days after a collision in orbit, an official at mission control said on Saturday.

"The situation on Mir is completely under the control of mission control and the crew," Vladimir Solovyov, who is responsible for flight coordination at Korolyov mission control near Moscow, told reporters.

Solovyov said 30 to 40 percent of Mir's electric power potential had been lost during Wednesday's accident, when a cargo craft collided with the space station during a docking manoeuvre and holed a scientific module attached to it.
"This is a very big figure," he said, but added that there was no need for the two Russians and one American on board Mir to conserve electricity.
Solovyov also said there was enough fuel on Mir for it to carry out manoeuvres as required.

He confirmed that a cargo craft would be launched on July 5 to take equipment to Mir to help restore the power supply. The repair work in the damaged Spektr scientific module will take place between July 10 and 14, he said.
Solovyov said the crew would spend Saturday checking how Mir's batteries were charging, trying to reduce humidity on the station and attempting to increase the oxygen supply.
They would switch on equipment which produces oxygen automatically on Sunday, he said.
He said the crew -- American Michael Foale and Russians Vasily Tsibliyev and Alexander Lazutkin -- would start training on Monday in preparation to carry out the repair work.
